\#\#\# User: I have installed **TightVNCServer** on Raspbian (the September 2\.017 version) for my Raspberry Pi 2 B\+ : 

```
luis@Frambuesio:~$  vncserver -name Frambuesio -geometry 1280x1024 -depth 16

New 'Frambuesio' desktop at :1 on machine Frambuesio

Starting applications specified in /etc/X11/Xvnc-session
Log file is /home/luis/.vnc/Frambuesio:1.log

Use xtigervncviewer -SecurityTypes VncAuth -passwd /home/luis/.vnc/passwd :1 to connect to the VNC server.

luis@Frambuesio:~$ netstat -ano | grep "5901"
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:5901          0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 ::1:5901                :::*                    LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)

```

But my VNC Viewer (from RealVNC on a remote Windows machine) receives the message "**Connection refused**" when trying to connect, and the port doesn't seem to be listening:

```
luis@Hipatio:~$ sudo nmap Frambuesio- -p 5900,5901,5902
[sudo] password for luis:

Starting Nmap 7.01 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2017-10-18 16:58 CEST
Nmap scan report for Frambuesio- (192.168.11.142)
Host is up (0.00050s latency).
PORT     STATE  SERVICE
5900/tcp closed vnc
5901/tcp closed vnc-1
5902/tcp closed vnc-2
MAC Address: B8:27:EB:7D:7C:B0 (Raspberry Pi Foundation)

Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 0.67 seconds

```

If I try from **Ubuntu** 16\.04\.3 on another Raspberry Pi everything goes all right (note the different `netstat` results):

```
luis@Zarzaparrillo:~$ vncserver -name Zarzaparrillo -geometry 1280x1024 -depth 16

New 'Zarzaparrillo' desktop is Zarzaparrillo:1

Starting applications specified in /home/luis/.vnc/xstartup
Log file is /home/luis/.vnc/Zarzaparrillo:1.log

luis@Zarzaparrillo:~$ netstat -ano | grep 5901
tcp6       0      0 :::5901                 :::*                    LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)

```

Same results with **VNC4Server**.

I have read the [official Raspberry papers](https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/remote-access/vnc/), consisting on installing the `realvnc-vnc-server` package. But the RealVNC program installs a ton of *extra packages* and is *not open source*, even when it is free for educative purposes. I would prefer some GNU's more open policies for my VNC, as long as it could be used in an enterprise production environment.

My **workaround** for now consists on using **X11vnc** to serve the display on another port:

```
luis@Frambuesio:~$  vncserver -name Frambuesio -geometry 1280x1024 -depth 16

[... on another terminal: ]
luis@Frambuesio:~$ sudo x11vnc -display :1 -passwd anypassword -auth guess -forever

```

... and now the X11vnc program makes display :1 available. Note that, as long as the port 5901 TCP is occupied, X11VNC uses the 5900 TCP (aka `:0 port`):

```
The VNC desktop is:      Frambuesio:0
PORT=5900

```

Note the `netstat` output, now in a **working** condition:

```
luis@Frambuesio:~$ netstat -ano | grep 5900
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:5900            0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 :::5900                 :::*                    LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)
luis@Frambuesio:~$ netstat -ano | grep 5901
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:5901          0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 ::1:5901                :::*                    LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)

```

Why are my VNC servers failing and how could I solve this?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The problem seems to be just a default argument on VNCServer with the improper (for your case) option. 

From `vncserver` command line help:

```
[-localhost yes|no]    Only accept VNC connections from localhost

```

This should solve your problem:

```
vncserver -localhost no

```

Interpreting the same last example in the original question, note the `0.0.0.0:5900` meaning "listening connections **from anywhere** at 5900 TCP":

```
luis@Frambuesio:~$ netstat -ano | grep 5900
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:5900            0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 :::5900                 :::*                    LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)

```

Meanwhile, note the `127.0.0.1:5901` meaning "listening connections **from localhost** at 5901 TCP"

```
luis@Frambuesio:~$ netstat -ano | grep 5901
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:5901          0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)
tcp6       0      0 ::1:5901                :::*                    LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)

```

Question: A system administrator is trying to set up VNC access on a Raspberry Pi running Raspbian. The VNCServer is installed and appears to be running, but remote connections are being refused. Given the following netstat output:

```
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:5901          0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      off (0.00/0/0)

To allow remote connections, the administrator should run vncserver with the -localhost no option, which will make it listen on all interfaces (0.0.0.0). This matches the information provided in the documentation about the -localhost option and how to resolve the issue.

\#\#\# User: I am on OSX 10\.9\.5\. I would like to use a later version of CURL than what is bundled with OSX, but I do not want to remove the OSX binary just in case, so I wanted to opt to install it via homebrew.

my PATH: 

```
$ echo $PATH
/Users/Tom/.nvm/v0.10.33/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin:/opt/X11/bin:/Users/Tom/.composer/vendor/bin:/usr/local/mysql/bin::~/Library/Trigger\ Toolkit:/usr/local/heroku/bin

```

as you can see, `/usr/local/bin` is almost at the front of the `path`, behind my Node `nvm` path.

result of `$ brew install curl`:

```
Warning: curl-7.38.0 already installed

```

result of `$ curl`:

```
dyld: Library not loaded: /usr/local/lib/libcurl.4.dylib
  Referenced from: /usr/local/bin/curl
  Reason: Incompatible library version: curl requires version 8.0.0 or later, but libcurl.4.dylib provides version 7.0.0
[1]    6481 trace trap  curl

```

What did I do wrong with the installation? Why didn't brew include the required libcurl version?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: One solution was provided [here](http://curl.haxx.se/mail/archive-2014-10/0072.html)

The idea is to make a static build of curl and then paste it to you /usr/bin/ or /usr/local/bin/. Briefly:

1. `~$ xcode-select --install`
2. Download the latest version of [curl](http://curl.haxx.se/download.html).
3. cd to the directory and run

`~$ ./configure --disable-shared --with-darwinssl --enable-threaded-resolver`

\~$ make \-j \`sysctl \-n hw.logicalcpu\_max\`
4. Copy the compiled curl, which is located in ./src/curl to you /usr/bin/

**Note:** In the make command in 3, the sign "\`" is indeed back quote, not single quote.

42.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are using OSX 10.9.5 and want to install a newer version of curl using Homebrew. After installation, you encounter an error about an incompatible library version. What is the recommended solution to resolve this issue?

A) Uninstall the OSX bundled version of curl and rely solely on the Homebrew version
B) Modify the PATH environment variable to prioritize the Homebrew curl installation
C) Compile a static build of curl from source and manually place it in /usr/local/bin/
D) Downgrade the Homebrew curl installation to match the system library version

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The recommended solution is to compile a static build of curl from source and manually place it in /usr/local/bin/. This approach avoids conflicts with system libraries and ensures compatibility. The process involves:

1. Installing Xcode command line tools
2. Downloading the latest curl source code
3. Configuring the build with specific options: --disable-shared --with-darwinssl --enable-threaded-resolver
4. Compiling curl using make
5. Manually copying the compiled curl binary to /usr/local/bin/

This method creates a standalone curl binary that doesn't depend on system-provided dynamic libraries, thus resolving the incompatibility issue.

Option A is incorrect as it may cause system instability. Option B doesn't address the core incompatibility issue. Option D would defeat the purpose of installing a newer version of curl.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In VHDL, when using a clocked process (triggered by a rising edge) to implement an adder, why might you need to press a button twice to see the output change on LEDs?

A) The synthesis tool optimizes out redundant logic, requiring multiple button presses.
B) VHDL processes execute sequentially, causing a one-cycle delay in output updates.
C) Signal assignments within a process are evaluated concurrently, but updated at the end of the process, causing a one-cycle delay.
D) The button debouncing circuit requires multiple presses to register a valid input.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. In VHDL processes, signal assignments (using <=) are handled in a special way. First, all right-side expressions are evaluated using the current signal values. Then, at the end of the process, all left-side signals are updated simultaneously. This behavior creates a one-cycle delay between input changes and output updates, which is why you might need to press the button twice to see the effect. This is different from concurrent statements outside of processes, which would update immediately. Options A, B, and D are incorrect or unrelated to the specific behavior described in the question.

\#\#\# User: Where could I find the Tikz Manual version 3\.0\.1a as a PDF file ?

More generally, how do I find the documentation for a package.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There are at least four ways to find the documentation of a package or class.

1\. `texdoc`
------------

Both TeXLive and MikTeX provide the `texdoc` command line tool which will usually find the correct documentation for a package with the following command:

```
 texdoc <package-name>

```

For example, to find the TikZ (or pgf) manual you can just type:

```
texdoc pgf

```

If that doesn't bring up the right documentation, (it usually does) you can ask it to provide a list of possible options by entering:

```
texdoc -s <package-name>

```

This will give you a numbered list of possible documents to choose from.

### Distribution differences

If you install TeXLive, documentation for packages is included by default with a full installation. 
If you install MikTeX, documentation may not be installed by default and you may need to use the package manager to install it.

2\. From within your editor
---------------------------

Many TeX IDEs provide access to `texdoc` through a menu item. This will depend on the actual editor, but looking in the Help menu is usually a place to start.

3\. texdoc.org
--------------

There is an online version of `texdoc` that allows you to get the PDF documentation through the web directly: The URL will have the form:

```
http://texdoc.org/pkg/<packagename>

```

So for your example:

```
http://texdoc.net/pkg/pgf

```

4\. CTAN
--------

All of the packages in TeXLive and MikTeX are hosted on [CTAN](https://www.ctan.org/), the Comprehensive TeX Archive Network.

As a last resort you can search there for the package and its documentation will be there too.

Documentation of the core LaTeX commands
----------------------------------------

If you want to find documentation of commands that are part of the LaTeX kernel, you can find them documented in the following documents. The first documents the basic LaTeX commands, and the second documents the new LaTeX3 commands that have been added in recent years.

```
 texdoc latex2e 

 texdoc interface3

```

B) Searching for the package on CTAN (Comprehensive TeX Archive Network)
C) Visiting the URL 'http://texdoc.org/pkg/tikz'
D) Looking in the 'References' section of your LaTeX editor's help menu

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
Option A is correct as 'texdoc pgf' is the recommended command to find TikZ documentation.
Option B is valid as CTAN hosts all TeXLive and MikTeX packages and their documentation.
Option C is correct, as texdoc.org provides online access to package documentation.
Option D is incorrect because while many LaTeX editors offer access to documentation, it's not a standard feature and the location isn't necessarily in a 'References' section of a help menu. This option is the least reliable of the four.

The question tests understanding of various methods to access LaTeX package documentation, as outlined in the provided information.

I would like to create a tibble with 0 rows and `length(tbl_colnames)` columns.

The best way I've found of doing this is...

`tbl <- as_tibble(data.frame(matrix(nrow=0,ncol=length(tbl_colnames)))`

and then I want to name the columns so...

`colnames(tbl) <- tbl_colnames`.

My question: Is there a more elegant way of doing this?

something like `tbl <- tibble(colnames=tbl_colnames)`

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Since you want to combine a list of tibbles. You can just assign NULL to the variable and then `bind_rows` with other tibbles. 

```
res = NULL
for(i in tibbleList)
   res = bind_rows(res,i)

```

However, a much efficient way to do this is 

```
bind_rows(tibbleList) # combine all tibbles in the list

```

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: You are working on a data analysis project and need to combine multiple tibbles with varying column names into a single tibble. You have a list called `tibble_list` containing these tibbles. Which of the following methods is the most efficient and concise way to achieve this in R?

A) Use a for loop to iterate through the list and combine tibbles:
```R
result <- NULL
for (tbl in tibble_list) {
  result <- bind_rows(result, tbl)
}
```

B) Use the `do.call()` function with `rbind()`:
```R
result <- do.call(rbind, tibble_list)
```

C) Use the `bind_rows()` function directly on the list:
```R
result <- bind_rows(tibble_list)
```

D) Create an empty tibble and use `rbind()` in a loop:
```R
result <- tibble()
for (tbl in tibble_list) {
  result <- rbind(result, tbl)
}
```

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most efficient and concise way to combine multiple tibbles from a list. The `bind_rows()` function from the dplyr package can directly accept a list of tibbles as an argument, automatically handling column name differences and combining the tibbles vertically. This method is more efficient than iterative approaches (options A and D) and more flexible than `do.call(rbind, ...)` (option B) when dealing with tibbles that may have different column names or structures. It also requires the least amount of code, making it the most elegant solution for the given problem.

\#\#\# User: This might be a ridiculous post, but let's say we have a file called `-|h4k3r|-`, why doesn't this quoting work?

```bsh
cat '-|h4k3r|-'

```

I thought single quotes remove meaning of all special characters?

However this one works

```bsh
cat -- -\|h4k3r\|- 

```

This one too:

```bsh
cat "./-|h4k3r|-"

```

But I don't get why this doesn't work?

```bsh
cat "-|h4k3r|-"

```

I'm only trying to understand why quoting doesn't work as expected in this example.

Maybe Bash has a special meaning for `'-` or `"-` ??

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The reason is that while single quotes actually remove the meaning of special characters, this refers to [variable expansion, globbing and word splitting](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Shell-Expansions.html) \- i.e. those characters that are special *to the shell* and that are interpreted by the shell *before the result is passed to the program* \- and shell metacharacters (such as the `|`).

The `-` is not a "special character" in that sense. What makes it special is that it is a *de facto* standard way to indicate to a program that the string started by it is an "option" argument. In fact, many (if not most) programs in the Unix/Linux ecosystem rely on the external [`getopt()`](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Getopt) function for that purpose1, which is part of the POSIX specification and provides a standardized way to handle command\-line parameters, and the convention of interpreting parameters that start with `-` as "options" is embedded there.

So, the single quotes ensure that the `-|h4ker|-` is passed verbatim from the shell to the program (`cat` in your case), [but also removes the quotes in that process](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Quote-Removal.html). Hence the program still thinks that since this parameter starts with a `-`, it should be treated as an "option" argument, not an operand (like a file name to process).

This is the reason why many programs (again, all that rely on `getopt()`) interpret the `--` token on the command line as a special "end\-of\-options" indicator, so that they can safely be applied to files that start with `-`.

Another possibility, which you already explored in your investigation, is to "protect" the filename by either stating it as an absolute filename (`'/path/to/file/-|h4ker|-'`) or prepend the current directory (`'./-|h4ker|-'`), because then, the argument will no longer start with the "ambiguous" `-`. *Note that quoting/escaping is still necessary in this example* because the `|` is a shell metacharacter.

A nice demonstration is trying to create and list a file named `-l`:

```
~$ touch '-l'
touch: Invalid option -- l
~$ touch -- '-l'
~$ ls '-l'

< ... the entire directory content in long list format ... >

~$ ls -- '-l'
-l
~$ ls -l -- '-l'
-rw-r--r-- 1 user user 0 Feb 24 17:16 -l

```

---

1 For shell scripts, there is an equivalent [`getopts`](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Getopts) builtin command

48.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: When working with files that have names starting with a hyphen (-) in Unix/Linux systems, which of the following statements is true?

A) Single quotes around the filename will always ensure the file is treated as a regular file and not as an option argument.

B) The `--` token before the filename is recognized by all programs to indicate the end of option arguments.

C) Prepending './' to the filename will prevent it from being interpreted as an option, but may still require quoting or escaping of shell metacharacters.

D) Double quotes around the filename will consistently prevent it from being interpreted as an option argument.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because single quotes only prevent shell expansion and interpretation of metacharacters, but don't change how the program interprets arguments starting with '-'.
B is incorrect because while many programs recognize '--' as the end-of-options indicator, it's not universal for all programs.
C is correct. Prepending './' ensures the argument doesn't start with '-', preventing option interpretation. However, shell metacharacters may still need quoting or escaping.
D is incorrect as double quotes, like single quotes, don't change how the program interprets arguments starting with '-'.

The key is understanding that the hyphen issue is related to how programs interpret arguments, not just shell parsing. Prepending './' changes the argument structure while potentially still requiring protection from shell interpretation.

\#\#\# User: I'm a LyX user. Can I move all (or most) of the TeX related files/folders to another (Linux) partition (`/data`) and so reuse that partition for LyX\-TeX after OS re\-install, as well as share that TeX partition between two distros (Lubuntu and Mageia LXDE)?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The TeX Live binaries "know" the location of the TeX Live tree (files, fonts and so on), because they set implicitly some environment variables whose value depends on the location of the binaries themselves.

On a Unix system it's so sufficient that the `PATH` environment variable contains a pointer to the binaries, for example something like

```
/usr/local/texlive/2011/bin/x86_64-linux:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin

```

(How to set the `PATH` variable is very system dependent). If you want to move the TeX Live tree to a `/data` partition, do it so that it's in

```
/data/texlive

```

and modify the `PATH` variable so that the location for the binaries is

```
/data/texlive/2011/bin/x86_64-linux

```

The final bit depends on the operating system, just look what's in the `texlive/2011/bin` directory to find the name.

It won't be a problem to share the tree between two GNU/Linux distributions, so long as they use the same binaries. But it's also possible to have more than one set of binaries (say the 32 bit and the 64 bit varieties): all you need is to have the correct pointer in the `PATH` variable.

A method that I find very easy to manage is to create a symbolic link:

```
ln -s /data/texlive/2011/bin/x86_64-linux /usr/texbin

```

(or `/opt/texbin` if one prefers) and use `/usr/texbin` in the PATH variable. In this way, when the update to TeX Live 2012 is available, it can be installed directly under `/data/texlive` (by modifying the default directory at installation time) and all that's needed to activate the new binaries becomes

```
rm /usr/texbin
ln -s /data/texlive/2012/bin/x86_64-linux /usr/texbin

```

(with suitable privileges, of course), without modifying the personal `.profile` file or any global file.

Similar symbolic links can be created for man pages and info files.

49.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided TeX Live documentation:

Question: You want to share a TeX Live installation between two Linux distributions and make it easily updatable. Which combination of steps would achieve this goal most effectively?

A) Install TeX Live in /usr/local/texlive and modify PATH in each distribution's global configuration files.

B) Install TeX Live in /data/texlive, create a symbolic link like /usr/texbin pointing to the current version's binaries, and add /usr/texbin to PATH.

C) Install separate TeX Live instances for each distribution and synchronize them manually.

D) Install TeX Live in /home/user/texlive and modify each user's .profile to include the correct PATH.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B is the most effective solution because:

1. Installing TeX Live in /data/texlive allows it to be shared between distributions and persist across OS reinstalls.
2. Creating a symbolic link (e.g., /usr/texbin) pointing to the current version's binaries makes it easy to switch between versions by simply updating the link.
3. Adding /usr/texbin to PATH in each distribution's configuration ensures the correct binaries are always used.
4. This method requires minimal configuration changes when updating TeX Live, as only the symbolic link needs to be updated.

Option A is less flexible for updates and sharing between distributions. Option C is inefficient and prone to inconsistencies. Option D makes sharing between users more difficult and doesn't persist across OS reinstalls.

\#\#\# User: Assuming a sample of random variables where the error terms for each random variable ($y\_{i}$) are given by $\\epsilon\_{1}, \\dots, \\epsilon\_{n} \\sim N(0, \\sigma^{2})$, a linear model is developed such that:

$$ y\_{i} \= \\beta\_{0} \+ \\epsilon\_{i} $$

then, using OLS, finding,

$$ \\frac{d}{d\\hat{\\beta}\_{0}} \\sum\_{i}^{n}(y\_{i} \- \\hat{\\beta}\_{0})^{2} \= 0 $$

and solving for $\\hat{\\beta}\_{0}$ yields, $\\hat{\\beta}\_{0} \= \\frac{1}{n}\\sum\_{i}^{n} y\_{i} \= \\bar{y}$

However, now, let's assume that there are *two* random variables where the error terms for the corresponding random variable ($y\_{i}$) are given by $\\epsilon\_{1} \\sim N(0, \\sigma^{2})$ and $\\epsilon\_{2} \\sim N(0, n\\sigma^{2})$.

Once again, the a linear model is developed such that:

$$ y\_{i} \= \\beta\_{0} \+ \\epsilon\_{i} $$

Can the estimator for $\\beta\_{0}$ given above be used for this model? If not, in light of the heteroscedasticity involved in the error terms, how is an estimator for $\\beta\_{0}$ developed?

I've seen linear models that, given a data point, use indicator functions to determine which terms in the model are non\-zero. Perhaps this applies here?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you know which distribution your samples are coming from, you can use [weighted least squares](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Least_squares#Weighted_least_squares). In particular, 

> The Gauss–Markov theorem shows that, when this is so,
>  $\\hat{\\boldsymbol{\\beta}}$ is a [best linear unbiased estimator](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Best_linear_unbiased_estimator) (BLUE). 
>  If, however, the measurements are uncorrelated but
>  have different uncertainties, a modified approach might be adopted.
>  Alexander Aitken showed that when a weighted sum of squared
>  residuals is minimized, $\\hat{\\boldsymbol{\\beta}}$ is BLUE
>  if each weight is equal to the reciprocal of the variance of the
>  measurement.

so give weights
$w\_i\=\\frac{1}{{\\sigma\_i}^2}$.

50.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In a study, researchers are analyzing two random variables Y1 and Y2, where Y1 ~ N(β0, σ²) and Y2 ~ N(β0, nσ²). They want to estimate β0 using the weighted least squares method. Which of the following weight assignments would result in the Best Linear Unbiased Estimator (BLUE) for β0?

A) w1 = 1, w2 = 1
B) w1 = 1, w2 = 1/n
C) w1 = n, w2 = 1
D) w1 = 1/σ², w2 = 1/(nσ²)

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: According to the Gauss-Markov theorem and Aitken's result, the Best Linear Unbiased Estimator (BLUE) is obtained when each weight is equal to the reciprocal of the variance of the measurement. For Y1, the variance is σ², so w1 = 1/σ². For Y2, the variance is nσ², so w2 = 1/(nσ²). Option D correctly assigns these weights, which will result in the BLUE for β0.

Option A uses equal weights, which doesn't account for the different variances. Option B and C attempt to adjust for the difference but don't use the correct reciprocal relationship. Only option D properly applies the principle of weighting by the reciprocal of the variance for each measurement.

\#\#\# User: I'm trying to solve the following congruence:

$71x\-1 \\equiv 0 \\pmod{59367} $ 

Given that $59367\=771 \\times 77$, I have previously solved that:

$71x \\equiv 1 \\pmod{771}$ such that $x\=\-76$

$71x \\equiv 1 \\pmod{77}$ such that $x\=\-13$

I'm trying to use the Chinese Remainder Theorem, but seem to be getting the wrong answer, if anyone can work this out so I can try and understand where it is that I'm going wrong?

Thank you

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Easy. There are exactly five subfields of ${\\mathbb Q}(\\sqrt{2},\\sqrt{3})$ : 
$K\_1\={\\mathbb Q},K\_2\={\\mathbb Q}(\\sqrt{2}),
K\_3\={\\mathbb Q}(\\sqrt{3}), K\_4\={\\mathbb Q}(\\sqrt{6}), K\_5\={\\mathbb Q}(\\sqrt{2},\\sqrt{3})$
 and ${\\mathbb Q}(\\gamma)$ is one of them.

It follows that $\\gamma$ is a primtive element iff
 $\\gamma\\not\\in K\_2,\\gamma\\not\\in K\_3,$ and $\\gamma\\not\\in K\_4$.

Writing $\\gamma\=c\_1\+c\_2\\sqrt{2}\+c\_3\\sqrt{3}\+c\_4\\sqrt{6}$, this is equivalent
 to $(c\_3,c\_4\)\\neq(0,0\),(c\_2,c\_3\)\\neq(0,0\),(c\_2,c\_4\)\\neq(0,0\)$, in other words
 at most one of $c\_2,c\_3,c\_4$ is zero.

51.answer:
Question: Consider the field extension Q(√2, √3). Which of the following statements is true regarding a primitive element γ = a + b√2 + c√3 + d√6 of this extension over Q?

A) γ is a primitive element if and only if exactly one of b, c, or d is non-zero
B) γ is a primitive element if and only if at least two of b, c, or d are non-zero
C) γ is a primitive element if and only if all of b, c, and d are non-zero
D) γ is a primitive element if and only if at most one of b, c, or d is zero

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The question is based on the characterization of primitive elements in the field extension Q(√2, √3). A primitive element γ generates the entire field extension. 

The key insight is that γ should not be contained in any proper subfield of Q(√2, √3). There are five subfields: Q, Q(√2), Q(√3), Q(√6), and Q(√2, √3) itself.

For γ to be a primitive element, it must not be in Q(√2), Q(√3), or Q(√6). This translates to the conditions:
- (c,d) ≠ (0,0) to not be in Q(√2)
- (b,d) ≠ (0,0) to not be in Q(√3)
- (b,c) ≠ (0,0) to not be in Q(√6)

These conditions are equivalent to saying that at most one of b, c, or d can be zero. This is precisely what option D states.

Option A is incorrect because it's too restrictive. Option B is close but not precise enough. Option C is too strict, as it unnecessarily requires all coefficients to be non-zero.

\#\#\# User: I'm currently taking an introduction to Solid State Physics class, and is now on the subject of superconductivity (SC). Currently I'm reading about the BCS theory, and how this works on a microscopic scale. I then get presented with this picture (Electron\-Phonon Interaction):

![Electron-Phonon interaction](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZJiFm.png)

Now, as far as I have understood, the electrons, when below $T\_{C}$, attract the ions, but are too fast compared to the ions, which means that the ions contract after the electron is gone. This creates a higher potential in the area where they are "squeezed" together which the next electron is much more attracted to that usually. This again means that all electrons pretty much follow the same path, and somehow bond together in Cooper Pairs (Is this the way they get entangled?).

Now, my main question is: Does this attraction of ions, after an electron has moved past them, not happen to a normal metal ? I mean, the electrons move in a normal metal, and also past ions. So don't they attract the ions as well, and make this attraction that another electron then can follow as well ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The attraction does happen at all temperature, but it is negligible if the temperature is too high. So the electrons do attract each other, but the thermal fluctuations do not allow for Cooper pairs to be stable.

To give an heuristic example : Imagine a lot of hydrogen atoms. The electrons are bound to their protons at zero temperature. If now you put the hydrogen atoms in a medium with a temperature high compare to 13eV (the binding energy), the electrons can take some energy from environment to leave their protons, and you don't have hydrogen atoms anymore, but a plasma (free protons and free electrons, interacting without forming bound states). The same thing happens with Cooper pairs : the temperature needs to be small enough to allow the physics to be dominated by these very weakly bounded pairs.

52.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the context of superconductivity and the BCS theory, which of the following statements best explains why the electron-phonon interaction does not lead to Cooper pair formation in normal metals at room temperature?

A) The electron-phonon interaction does not occur in normal metals at all.

B) The ions in normal metals are too heavy to be attracted by passing electrons.

C) The thermal energy at room temperature overcomes the weak attraction between electrons, preventing stable Cooper pair formation.

D) Electrons in normal metals move too slowly to create the necessary ion displacement for pair formation.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The electron-phonon interaction occurs in both normal metals and superconductors. However, in normal metals at room temperature, the thermal energy is too high compared to the weak attraction between electrons mediated by this interaction. This prevents the formation of stable Cooper pairs, which are essential for superconductivity. The thermal fluctuations provide enough energy to break apart any momentary pairing of electrons. Only when the temperature is lowered below the critical temperature (Tc) does the thermal energy become small enough for the attractive interaction to dominate, allowing Cooper pairs to form and remain stable. This is analogous to the example given with hydrogen atoms, where high temperatures can break apart bound states.

\#\#\# User: I'm asking this question because recently I've been seeing something which puzzles me quite a bit.

In one of the tags I follow there's one high\-rep user who is on a streak of poorly received questions. The last 10 ones or so (maybe more) all have a negative score, some are closed. I can imagine why, the reason I myself would downvote them is because they look rather lazy.

In fact, the ones that are not closed go on to receive answers from high\-rep answerers.

The message I'm getting from this is:

> "these kind of questions do not fit the standard, but we will answer them anyway".

#### **Why?**

I'm all about helping other fellow programmers, but this seems contradictory. I understand that downvotes and flags on answers convey two very different meanings.

On the other hand, I don't see this for questions. If you downvote a question, and even more so if you vote to close it, you are essentially saying: "this post has problems", for example: it doesn't include enough details, it's poorly formatted, it's not reproducible, it doesn't show effort, etc. Which are more or less the same reasons available when flagging for close.

---

Does a streak of poorly received questions **not** affect the poster in any way? If they keep contributing content that doesn't pass scrutiny, I would expect that to reflect on them somehow.

So what is going on? Are poorly received questions fine, as long as they can reasonably be of help to others? What is the rule of thumb?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A streak of poorly received questions does not *really* impact users with relatively high reputation.

Based on the ban message and observed ban cases to hit the ban one needs to have consistently non\-positive average contribution in questions or answers correspondingly (there are likely other factors but average votes seem to have the most impact). So if one occasionally posts useful questions it is very likely to outweigh all negative contribution. Additionally negative votes are essentially capped to 3 (to allow deletion) and in super rare cases reach 10\-15 (posts that are either outrageously rude or asking for malicious code) while upvotes are unbounded \- this makes it even less likely to meet condition of the ban.

For possible action as [Cody Gray said in a comment](https://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/398811/does-a-streak-of-poorly-received-questions-not-affect-the-poster#comment778813_398811) use custom flag if you feel necessary:

> ...by raising a confidential flag on one of their posts and highlighting the pattern of recent, low\-quality questions.  
> 
> ...Yes, I mean a custom flag. I used the word "confidential" to make clear that moderator flags are confidential, which avoids concerns about publicly calling out a particular user (which you wouldn't want to do on Meta).

Using a custom flag is especially recommended when you are tempted to downvote all recent questions by the author triggering "revenge downvote" pattern. This is very likely to happen in such "streak of bad questions" cases ("you *censored* posted 4 nearly identical questions and did not even look at comments"). If that happens the safest option is to custom flag and to consider ignoring posts from that user for some time for your own sake.

Note so that lack of research alone does not make the question off\-topic on Stack Overflow. Such questions are still eligible for answers and may even eventually collect positive votes as being useful (ideally someone would improve question too, but that is not strictly required).

\#\#\# User: I've been thinking of ways to do home automation that is somewhat future proof (hardwired); and the best idea I have is to use relays for lights on a 3 way switch circuit. Put in a dual pole dual throw relay and have it emulate a 4 way switch. Also add a [current sensor](http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/B008ASXVL4) so I can tell if the light is on or off (secondary goal). All the lighting circuit wiring is in the attic (1 story house) so I'll splice the box in above. Due to the nature of the way a [4 way switch works](http://users.wfu.edu/matthews/misc/switches/4WayAnimation.html) this should be passive and allow for simple switches to be used unlike what I saw here [Any obvious problems with this DIY home automation?](https://diy.stackexchange.com/questions/28906/any-obvious-problems-with-this-diy-home-automation). Also means that if the automation logic is removed the switches will work as normal. I can put these in now and worry about hardware/software later; having all control and sensor wires run back to a central location.

Question is what relay do I need to get, and how would I wire it up in order to accomplish this task? I was thinking of using 24vac coils because they are very common (in homes) but that makes it harder to hook up to a logic board as I'll need another relay to convert DC to AC for the coil on the 120v (USA) relay.

Pretty sure I would need a DTDP (or 2x STDP) latching relay but I'm not sure which one to get and how to wire it up so that the circuits cross like X or goes parallel like \= when given a switch signal. 

Making all switches be 3 way wouldn't be that hard to do in this house; so I could do this for every light switch without too much hassle.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can purchase and utilize a common DPDT type relay (Double Pole / Double Throw) to create a cross over switch. It is pretty easy to understand from the following relay diagram:

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/kpcp7.png)

You connect one circuit to the two NC (normally closed) terminals of the relay. The other circuit connects to the two COM (common) terminals. Then you add two additional wires which cross connect the two NC terminals to the opposite NO (normally open) terminals. 

The coil of course is driven with the control voltage that you have selected. The simplest control voltage to use would be \+12V DC. There are plenty of relays available that have 12V DC coils and your remote automation control can use simple transistors to drive the relay coils. 

If you go ahead and use 24V AC for the relay coils then you would have to use an additional relay for each switch control to translate the switching from the AC realm to the low voltage DC realm. (There are circuit components available that can switch the 24VAC but it gets more complex than necessary for an application where \+12V DC can be easily used instead. And then you can derive the needed \+12V DC from a re\-purposed computer power supply. 

A major concern when building any type of system such as this, where you bring remote control wiring into the mains wiring boxes of your house, is safety and isolation. Only relays rated properly should be used and you would bear the safety liability associated with stringing the control wires around your house.

54.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a home automation system using relays to emulate 4-way switches, which of the following statements is correct regarding the relay configuration and wiring?

A) A Single Pole Single Throw (SPST) relay is sufficient to create the crossover switch functionality.

B) The two circuits should be connected to the NO (Normally Open) and COM (Common) terminals of the relay.

C) A Double Pole Double Throw (DPDT) relay with cross-connected terminals can be used to create the desired switching behavior.

D) 24V AC is the recommended control voltage for the relay coils in this setup due to its simplicity and compatibility with automation logic boards.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. A Double Pole Double Throw (DPDT) relay can be used to create a crossover switch functionality for a 4-way switch emulation in home automation. As shown in the diagram, one circuit connects to the two NC (Normally Closed) terminals, the other to the two COM (Common) terminals, with additional cross-connections between NC and NO (Normally Open) terminals. This configuration allows for the necessary switching behavior.

Answer A is incorrect because a Single Pole Single Throw (SPST) relay does not have enough terminals or switching capabilities for this application.

Answer B is incorrect as the correct connection is to use NC and COM terminals, not NO and COM.

Answer D is incorrect because while 24V AC is common in homes, it's not the recommended control voltage for this setup. The documentation suggests using 12V DC as a simpler option that's easier to integrate with automation logic and can be derived from a repurposed computer power supply.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Geoserver](http://geoserver.org/display/GEOS/Welcome) probably is the most known option among the open\-source feature server applications. However, I personally use MapServer.

Here you can check some info about both applications:

1. [http://www.slideshare.net/ssuser185516/mapserver\-vs\-geoserver\-16107836](http://www.slideshare.net/ssuser185516/mapserver-vs-geoserver-16107836)

3. [http://anitagraser.com/2010/06/08/geoserver\-vs\-mapserver/](http://anitagraser.com/2010/06/08/geoserver-vs-mapserver/)

To answer your second question (about commercial GIS apps), the "Mercedes Benz" of the GIS applications is [ArcGis](http://www.esri.com/software/arcgis) (based on some lists such as [http://www.gisdoctor.com/site/gis\-help/commercial\-gis\-software/](http://www.gisdoctor.com/site/gis-help/commercial-gis-software/)).

However, I think you can achieve lot of GIS capabilities with two open\-source software projects, these are:

1. [QGis](http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)
2. [GRASS](http://grass.osgeo.org/)

Wikipedia is a good source to search for more open\-source and commercial applications: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_geographic_information_systems_software>

Hope this helps,

\#\#\# User: I have the items in my data attribute table, which were selected. What I want to do is make the object with the same value to be selected in the attribute table, which belongs to another layer. In both cases, the considered column is called `"new_name"`.

If for instance the `"new_name"` value has been selected in the left attribute table I need exactly the same value to be selected in the other attribute table.

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/fJvtM.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/fJvtM.png)

How can I make the selection such as this?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I can suggest a solution with PyQGIS.

Proceed with `Plugins > Python Console > Show Editor` and paste the script below

```py
layer1 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Final cellsites')[0]
layer2 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Lighting columns')[0]

field1 = "new_name"
field2 = "new_name"

selected_features = [feat[field1] for feat in layer1.selectedFeatures()]

selected_attributes = f'({selected_features[0]})' if len(selected_features) == 1 else tuple(selected_features)

expression = f'"{field2}" in {selected_attributes}'

layer2.selectByExpression(expression)

```

Press `Run script` [![run script](https://i.stack.imgur.com/vHkKx.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/vHkKx.png) and get the output that will look like

[![example](https://i.stack.imgur.com/wxQiu.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/wxQiu.png)

---

**References:**

* [How to create a tuple with only one element](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12876177/how-to-create-a-tuple-with-only-one-element)
* [Selecting features using expression with PyQGIS](https://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/131158/selecting-features-using-expression-with-pyqgis)
* [Getting attributes of selected features using PyQGIS](https://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/31799/getting-attributes-of-selected-features-using-pyqgis)
* [Select features from another layer based on a selection in PyQGIS](https://gis.stackexchange.com/questions/256569/select-features-from-another-layer-based-on-a-selection-in-pyqgis)
* [PyQGIS Developer Cookbook](https://docs.qgis.org/latest/en/docs/pyqgis_developer_cookbook/index.html#pyqgis-developer-cookbook)

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are working with two QGIS layers: 'Final cellsites' and 'Lighting columns'. Both layers have a field called "new_name". You want to select features in the 'Lighting columns' layer based on the selected features in the 'Final cellsites' layer, matching the "new_name" values. Which of the following PyQGIS code snippets would correctly accomplish this task?

A)
```python
layer1 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Final cellsites')[0]
layer2 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Lighting columns')[0]
selected_features = [feat["new_name"] for feat in layer1.selectedFeatures()]
expression = f'"new_name" = {selected_features}'
layer2.selectByExpression(expression)
```

B)
```python
layer1 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Final cellsites')[0]
layer2 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Lighting columns')[0]
selected_features = [feat["new_name"] for feat in layer1.selectedFeatures()]
selected_attributes = f'({selected_features[0]})' if len(selected_features) == 1 else tuple(selected_features)
expression = f'"new_name" in {selected_attributes}'
layer2.selectByExpression(expression)
```

C)
```python
layer1 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Final cellsites')[0]
layer2 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Lighting columns')[0]
selected_features = layer1.selectedFeatures()
expression = f'"new_name" in {selected_features}'
layer2.select(expression)
```

D)
```python
layer1 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Final cellsites')[0]
layer2 = QgsProject.instance().mapLayersByName('Lighting columns')[0]
selected_features = [feat["new_name"] for feat in layer1.selectedFeatures()]
for feature in layer2.getFeatures():
    if feature["new_name"] in selected_features:
        layer2.select(feature.id())
```

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B is the correct answer because it properly handles both single and multiple selections, creates the correct expression format, and uses the appropriate selection method.

A is incorrect because it doesn't properly format the expression for both single and multiple selections.
C is incorrect because it tries to use the feature objects directly in the expression, which won't work, and uses an incorrect selection method.
D is incorrect because while it would work, it's less efficient as it loops through all features in layer2 instead of using a single expression-based selection.

\#\#\# User: I have a line layer (representing a pipeline) and a points layer (representing valves) and I would like to calculate the chainage of the valves along the pipeline. 

I assume that I would first need to 'snap' the points to the line in order to calculate chainage as they do not currently lie directly above the line. However I would need to use a bulk tool if possible as there are several hundred points and would take too long to do manually. 

I wondered whether the LRS tool in QGIS could be used to derive chainage? 

I am using QGIS 2\.2, GRASS \& Postgis. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can use the QGIS [plugin LRS](http://plugins.qgis.org/plugins/lrs/) for that. It accepts points not lying on the line, so you avoid the first step (snapping points to lines).

This is the workflow:

1. Based on both a line (routes) and a point (for calibration) layer, go to the **Calibration** tab. 

	* Select the line (pipeline) layer with its *route* field (a field that identifies routes, it's very useful if your line layer has several routes).
	* Select the calibration point layer with its corresponding *route* (point *route* value should match with the line *route* value) and *measure* fields. As you can see, you would need a calibration point layer with at least two points, which could be located at the start and the end of the route, with values of 0 and 10000 in case that the route has 10km.![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/5K9dA.png)

	* Click on Ok to interpolate M values along the routes.
2. Go to the **Measures** tab. 

	* Select your valves layer.
	* Fill the output fields (They'll be applied to a new layer, don't worry).
	* Click on Ok to get a new (memory) layer which will contain the M value (chainage) of each valve.
3. Don't forget to save the layer you obtain from 2\., since it's a memory (temporal) layer.

---

In the following screenshot you can see a sample pipeline, a couple of calibration points (orange triangles), and a couple of valves not lying on the pipeline (green points) with their calculated chainage (M value).

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/dwIRH.png)

You can even verify the chainage of the valves by using the **Locate** tab. Just select your route and enter a known measure (e.g., 5603\). You should see a yellow mark on the line, representing the projection of the valve on the line.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/hAPRi.png)

I use QGIS v.2\.6\.1\. You can find documentation of LRS plugin [here](http://blazek.github.io/lrs/release/help.0.3.5/index.html).

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: You are working on a GIS project involving a pipeline network and need to calculate the chainage of valves along the pipeline. You have a line layer representing the pipeline and a points layer representing the valves. The valve points are not directly on the pipeline. Using QGIS 2.2 with the LRS plugin, which of the following workflows is correct to achieve this task?

A) 1. Snap the valve points to the pipeline
   2. Use the Calibration tab to interpolate M values
   3. Use the Measures tab to calculate chainage
   4. Save the resulting memory layer

B) 1. Use the Calibration tab to interpolate M values
   2. Use the Measures tab to calculate chainage
   3. Use the Locate tab to verify results
   4. Save the resulting memory layer

C) 1. Use the Measures tab to calculate chainage
   2. Use the Calibration tab to interpolate M values
   3. Snap the valve points to the pipeline
   4. Use the Locate tab to verify results

D) 1. Snap the valve points to the pipeline
   2. Use the Measures tab to calculate chainage
   3. Use the Calibration tab to interpolate M values
   4. Use the Locate tab to verify results

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct workflow using the LRS plugin in QGIS for this task is option B. The LRS plugin doesn't require snapping the points to the line first, which is a key advantage. The Calibration tab is used first to interpolate M values along the routes, using the pipeline layer and calibration points. Then, the Measures tab is used to calculate the chainage for the valve points, even if they're not directly on the line. The Locate tab can be used to verify the results by projecting points onto the line at specific chainages. Finally, it's important to save the resulting memory layer as it's temporary by default. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because they either include unnecessary steps (like snapping) or have the steps in the wrong order.

\#\#\# User: In Goat Simulator, you can unlock mutators or power\-ups for your goat such as rockets or a ball launcher. While you can have one apparently active at the same time and use it via (R) is there anyway to switch between the two?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can have as many mutators active as you collect, in a normal mode, or select and collect, in a custom mode. However, be careful about selecting multiple mutators in custom mode, as character model mutators have a habit of conflicting with each other and making the custom game unplayable with that character.

Regarding 'R' mutators, unfortunately, there is currently no way to disable and enable specific ability mutators, causing all active mutators to trigger when you press R. For instance, if you have jetpack, devil, and pitcher mutators, when you press R, your demon powers and jetpack will toggle on, and a ball will be thrown.

Question: In Goat Simulator, which of the following statements is true regarding mutators and their functionality?

A) Players can only have one mutator active at a time, regardless of how many they've collected.
B) In custom mode, selecting multiple character model mutators always enhances gameplay without any conflicts.
C) Players can freely switch between different ability mutators using a designated key.
D) Pressing 'R' activates all currently equipped ability mutators simultaneously, potentially causing multiple effects.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because the documentation states that players can have as many mutators active as they collect in normal mode.
B is incorrect as the documentation warns about conflicts between character model mutators in custom mode, which can make the game unplayable.
C is incorrect because the documentation explicitly states there is no way to disable and enable specific ability mutators.
D is correct as the documentation explains that pressing 'R' triggers all active mutators, giving the example of demon powers, jetpack, and ball throwing all activating at once if those mutators are equipped.
